sentence.text: Prostate cancer is the most common cancer among western negative regulation of phosphatase activity, with a significant mortality and morbidity reported for advanced metastatic disease.

By analysing prostate cancer bone metastases using high density microarrays, we found a common genomic copy number loss at 6q16.1-16.2, containing the ubiquitin-dependent protein catabolic process gene, which was confirmed in larger series of bone metastases by fluorescence in situ hybridisation (superoxide metabolic process).

Loss of ubiquitin-dependent protein catabolic process was also detected in primary tumours and it was highly associated with prognostic factors including high Gleason score, clinical stage, prostate-specific antigen (plasminogen activation) and extent of disease, as well as poor patient survival, suggesting that ubiquitin-dependent protein catabolic process loss contributes to prostate cancer progression.
We also demonstrated that ubiquitin-dependent protein catabolic process deletion is detectable in circulating tumour cells (CTCs), making it a potential prognostic biomarker by 'liquid biopsy'.
In vitro analysis showed that ubiquitin-dependent protein catabolic process plays a role in regulating the migration and invasion of prostate cancer cells.
ubiquitin-dependent protein catabolic process potentially controls cancer metastasis through regulation of negative regulation of retrograde protein transport, ER to cytosol levels.

entity.text: negative regulation of retrograde protein transport, ER to cytosol

sentence.text: Therefore, ubiquitin-dependent protein catabolic process could be a potential novel prostate cancer suppressor gene, which may prevent cancer progression and metastasis through controlling cell invasion
